captions.text:
In the 19th century aristocrats from London
to Moscow flocked to France’s sunny

Cote d’Azur, or "blue coast." Much loved for its
blue seas and blue skies, this was the place

for Northern Europeans to socialize, gamble,
and escape their dreary weather.

Whether you’re rich or not, Nice, with its
eternally entertaining seafront promenade

and fine museums, is the enjoyable big-city
highlight of the Riviera.
In its traffic-free old city, Italian and French flavors mix to create a spicy Mediterranean dressing.

Nice may be nice, but it’s hot and jammed in
July and August. We’re here in early June…beating
the serious heat and crowds.

The broad Promenade des Anglais (literally
the "walkway of the English") was paved in

marble for blue-blooded 19th century English
tourists who wanted a safe place to stroll

and admire the view without getting their
shoes dirty or smelling that fishy gravel.

Today it’s a fun people’s scene with a
bike and roller blade path that leads all
the way to the airport.
The beach, while pebbly, is popular.

Whether you’re looking for 
an adrenalin rush or

just working on your suntan, this beach has
it all. Tan lines can be hard to find, as

Europeans are relaxed about topless sunbathing.
While major stretches of the beach are public,

much of it is private — where you pay to
rent a spot, complete with mattress, lounge
chair, and umbrella.
Nice was born on its easy-to-fortify hill. From there — and inland from the beach — spreads its colorful old town.
The old town squares feel more Italian than French because until 1860,
Nice was ruled by an Italian king. Until the mid-1800s, the people here spoke an Italian dialect .

Street signs are still in two
languages and pasta is still a favorite.
Nice's Italian rulers lived in this palace.

As the modern nation of Italy was being created,
this region was given a choice: join the chaotic

new country of Italy or join wealthy France
(which was enjoying good times under the rule

of Napoleon III). The vast majority of the
people voted to go French...and voilà!

The old town offers a cultural scavenger hunt
of opportunities, from its medieval market

square with fresh seasonal produce to a pasta
shop showing Nice's Italian roots, to the

nearby Patisserie Auer. Its belle époque
storefront brags that it’s been run

"From father to son since 1820.” Queen Victoria
satisfied her sweet tooth right here.

Socca — a thin chickpea crêpe, seasoned
with pepper and olive oil — is a peasant

staple pre-dating tourism that’s still dear
to local hearts. At this busy stand the socca

arrives by motorbike hot out of the oven and
is sold and gobbled up as quickly as they
can slice it.

Flowers seem to grow effortlessly and everywhere
in this ideal climate. This has long been

the Riviera’s biggest flower market. Fresh
flowers are a fine value in this otherwise

pricey city. And with such an abundance of
flowers, it’s no wonder perfume is a local
industry.

The Molinard family has been making perfume
from Cote d’Azur flowers for a century.

Perfume is “distilled like cognac and then
aged like wine.” It takes more than 400

pounds of lavender to produce just one quart
of pure essence. For the French, finding just
the right perfume is a personal quest.

title: Nice, France: Beaches, Pasta and Perfume

comments.text:
+cémoi encore Nizza had never been part of the italian state, because the 
King of sardinia, who would Have became the King of italy decided to give 
two regions of its Kingdom to France, these regions were savoy and the 
county of Nizza. Nizza Was the city of Giuseppe Garibaldi, one of the 
italy' father. Nizza Was annexed by France but a very big part of its 
population decided to remain sardinian and italian citizen and emigrated to 
italy. Sorry but i cant find a Wikipedia document in english or French, but 
u cant translate this : http://it.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vespri_nizzardi

Moreover, when the cities of mentone and roccabruna decided to be 
indipendent by the grimaldis of Monaco, they adopted the italian flag 
http://it.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Città_libere_di_Mentone_e_Roccabruna#/media/File:Flag_of_Menton_and_Roquebrune.gif

comments.text:
Your sentence isn't very good, there isn't only one French culture. I live 
near Lyon, where there isn't the same culture as Grenoble, Strasbourg, 
Bordeaux, Lille, Paris and Nice.
So each part of the France is different, and all the parts compose the 
French culture (Provencal, Alps, Basque, Alsacian...). Of course, there is 
a common base, and you can also find it in Nice.
But it is the same in all countries in the world. For example,  New York 
and Houston don't have the same exact culture, and they are both in USA (I 
don't think that all the Houston people knows that they live in the same 
country as the New York people lol...)
comments.author: Fabien Servanin

comments.author: Alexandros HoMegas

comments.text:
I went to Nice for a spontaneous 6-day trip this April and was amazed by 
the beauty of its old city centre and the amazing food culture. We dined 
out every single evening, on a budget, and I've never eaten better or more 
varied. Highly recommend Nice, and also touristy (in peak season), but 
still gorgeous artists village Eze (which is easily reached by bus from 
Nice).﻿
comments.author: Poppy M

comments.text:
He mis-represents the motive of the local English residents. They raised 
funds to provide employment for the poor French workers who were suffering 
severe unemployment after a devastating harvest failure. The Promenade des 
Anglais was the result.

comments.text:
Nizza was an Italian city until 1860 and then annexed to France through a 
rigged referendum, then they started with the policy of francisation , 
people last names were changed Bianchi became Le Blanc, Del Ponte became 
Dupont, Pastore became Pastor, etc, Italian language newspapers were shut 
down such La Voce di Nizza. Today Nizza/Nice is an homogeneous French city. 
One of the most important italian founding father " Giuseppe Garibaldi " 
was born in Nizza.

comments.text:
France has everything, the Mediterranean Sea and its Romanesque influences 
(Corsica, French Riviera), Provence, Mountains (Pyrennes, Alps), endless 
beaches for surfing (Landes), the salty air of the Atlantic ocean, cliffs 
and hedgerows of Normandy, the Celtic magnetism of Brittany. Extinct 
volcanoes of the Massif Central, the Germanness of Alsace and Lorraine, the 
Guyanese jungle, islands in the Caribbeans, French Polynesia and Paris to 
coordinate everything. What more ?
